answer_html:
\(\dim\text{null}(A - 2I) = 2.\)In conclusion,

  • For the eigenvalue 1, the dimension of its eigenspace is 1.

  • For the eigenvalue 2, the dimension of its eigenspace is 2.
answer_latex:
$\dim\text{null}(A - 2I) = 2.$In conclusion,\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  For the eigenvalue 1, the dimension of its eigenspace is 1.
\item
  For the eigenvalue 2, the dimension of its eigenspace is 2.
\end{itemize}
question: 7 (c)
sols_html:
From part (b), we know that the eigenvalues of A are 1 and 2. We also saw in part (b) that the eigenvalue 2 is a repeated root of the characteristic polynomial for A, while the eigenvalue 1 is not.

By definition, the dimension of each respective eigenspace is at least 1. As well, recall that the dimension of each eigenspace is at most the multiplicity of the eigenvalue as a root of the characteristic polynomial.

  • As the eigenvalue 1 is not a repeated root of the characteristic polynomial for A, the dimension of its eigenspace must be at least 1, and at most 1, i.e. it is equal to 1.

  • The eigenvalue 2 is a twice repeated root of the characteristic polynomial for A; therefore the dimension of its eigenspace may be either 1 or 2. We will need to investigate further to determine which one it is.

To calculate the dimension of the eigenspace corresponding to the eigenvalue 2, we want to determine \(\dim\text{null}(A - 2I)\), that is, the dimension of the kernel of A - 2I. We have

\(A - 2I = \begin{pmatrix} - 2& -4 & -6\\ -1 & - 2 & -3\\ 1 & 2 & 3 \end{pmatrix}.\)

All three rows of A - 2I are multiples of each other, so \(\text{rank}(A - 2I) = 1\). Therefore, by the rank-nullity theorem,

\(\dim\text{null}(A - 2I) = \dim(\mathbb{R}^3) - \dim \text{rank}(A - 2I) = 3 - 1 = 2.\)

In conclusion,

  • For the eigenvalue 1, the dimension of its eigenspace is 1.

  • For the eigenvalue 2, the dimension of its eigenspace is 2.
sols_latex:
From part (b), we know that the eigenvalues of \emph{A} are 1 and 2. We
also saw in part (b) that the eigenvalue 2 is a repeated root of the
characteristic polynomial for \emph{A}, while the eigenvalue 1 is not.

By definition, the dimension of each respective eigenspace is \emph{at
least 1}. As well, recall that the dimension of each eigenspace is
\emph{at most the multiplicity of the eigenvalue as a root of the
characteristic polynomial}.

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  As the eigenvalue 1 is not a repeated root of the characteristic
  polynomial for \emph{A}, the dimension of its eigenspace must be
  \emph{at least 1}, and \emph{at most 1}, i.e. it is equal to 1.
\end{itemize}

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  The eigenvalue 2 is a twice repeated root of the characteristic
  polynomial for \emph{A}; therefore the dimension of its eigenspace may
  be either 1 or 2. We will need to investigate further to determine
  which one it is.
\end{itemize}

To calculate the dimension of the eigenspace corresponding to the
eigenvalue 2, we want to determine $\dim\text{null}(A - 2I)$, that is,
the dimension of the kernel of \emph{A - 2I}. We have

$A - 2I = \begin{pmatrix} - 2& -4 & -6\\ -1 & - 2 & -3\\ 1 & 2 & 3 \end{pmatrix}.$

All three rows of \emph{A - 2I} are multiples of each other, so
$\text{rank}(A - 2I)  = 1$. Therefore, by the rank-nullity theorem,

$\dim\text{null}(A - 2I) = \dim(\mathbb{R}^3) - \dim \text{rank}(A - 2I) = 3 - 1 = 2.$

In conclusion,

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  For the eigenvalue 1, the dimension of its eigenspace is 1.
\item
  For the eigenvalue 2, the dimension of its eigenspace is 2.
\end{itemize}
sols_raw:
From part (b), we know that the eigenvalues of ''A'' are 1 and 2. We also saw in part (b) that the eigenvalue 2 is a repeated root of the characteristic polynomial for ''A'', while the eigenvalue 1 is not. 

By definition, the dimension of each respective eigenspace is ''at least 1''. As well, recall that the dimension of each eigenspace is ''at most the multiplicity of the eigenvalue as a root of the characteristic polynomial''.

* As the eigenvalue 1 is not a repeated root of the characteristic polynomial for ''A'', the dimension of its eigenspace must be ''at least 1'', and ''at most 1'', i.e. it is equal to 1.

* The eigenvalue 2 is a twice repeated root of the characteristic polynomial for ''A''; therefore the dimension of its eigenspace may be either 1 or 2. We will need to investigate further to determine which one it is.

To calculate the dimension of the eigenspace corresponding to the eigenvalue 2, we want to determine <math>\dim\text{null}(A - 2I)</math>, that is, the dimension of the kernel of ''A - 2I''. We have

<math>
 A - 2I = \begin{pmatrix} - 2& -4 & -6\\ -1 & - 2 & -3\\ 1 & 2 & 3 \end{pmatrix}.
</math>

All three rows of ''A - 2I'' are multiples of each other, so <math>\text{rank}(A - 2I)  = 1</math>. Therefore, by the rank-nullity theorem, 

<math>
\dim\text{null}(A - 2I) = \dim(\mathbb{R}^3) - \dim \text{rank}(A - 2I) = 3 - 1 = 2.
</math>

In conclusion,

*For the eigenvalue 1, the dimension of its eigenspace is 1.
* For the eigenvalue 2, the dimension of its eigenspace is 2.
statement_html: Consider the matrix \(A = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & -4 & -6\\ -1 & 0 & -3\\ 1 & 2 & 5 \end{pmatrix}\). For each eigenvalue, find the dimension of the corresponding eigenspace.
statement_latex:
Consider the matrix
$A = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & -4 & -6\\ -1 & 0 & -3\\ 1 & 2 & 5 \end{pmatrix}$.
For each eigenvalue, find the dimension of the corresponding eigenspace.
statement_raw: Consider the matrix <math> A = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & -4 & -6\\ -1 & 0 & -3\\ 1 & 2 & 5 \end{pmatrix} </math>. For each eigenvalue, find the dimension of the corresponding eigenspace.
